data.title: 9 Things to Do in Quezon City: Top Activities & Attractions
data.meta_description: Quezon City, a vibrant and diverse metropolis, offers art galleries, gardens, and shopping malls. Discover the urban things to do in Quezon City.
data.text:
Quezon City, one of the most populous cities in the Philippines, is a vibrant metropolis known for its rich history, diverse culture, and bustling urban life. For those pondering things to do in Quezon City, exploring the Quezon Memorial Circle, a national park and shrine dedicated to the Philippines‚Äô second President, Manuel L. Quezon, and visiting the Art in Island, an interactive 3D art museum, are top activities.

The city‚Äôs bustling Maginhawa Street offers a haven for food lovers, with numerous restaurants and cafes serving a wide variety of cuisines. Nearby, the La Mesa Eco Park provides a lush green space for recreation, with picnic areas, swimming pools, and hiking trails.

Beyond its urban attractions, Quezon City is also known for its educational institutions, including the University of the Philippines Diliman, which contributes to the city‚Äôs vibrant intellectual and cultural scene. For those seeking the best places to visit in the Philippines, Quezon City‚Äôs blend of historical significance, cultural richness, and urban energy makes it a compelling destination.

Attractions & Things to Do in Quezon City, Philippines

1. Quezon Memorial Circle

The towering Quezon Memorial Shrine at the heart of Quezon Memorial Circle is dedicated to the memory of the Philippines‚Äô second president, Manuel L. Quezon. The park surrounding the monument is a popular recreational area, complete with gardens, a museum, and a mausoleum where President Quezon and his wife are interred.

Travel Tip: The park is a great place for family picnics, and on weekends, you can find a variety of food stalls and live entertainment.

2. Art in Island

Art in Island is an interactive 3D art museum that encourages visitors to become part of the artwork with optical illusions that create playful scenes. It‚Äôs the largest of its kind in Asia, making for a fun and memorable experience.

Travel Tip: Wear white or bright colors to stand out in pictures, and make sure your camera or phone is fully charged‚Äîyou‚Äôll want to take lots of photos!

3. Eastwood City

Eastwood City is a 17-hectare commercial and residential development known for its IT park, mall, and various dining and entertainment options. It‚Äôs often described as a city within a city and is a popular hangout spot both day and night.

Travel Tip: Check out the schedule of events, as Eastwood City often hosts free concerts and shows, especially around holidays and weekends.

4. Maginhawa Street

Maginhawa Street is the heart of Quezon City‚Äôs food scene, offering a stretch of restaurants, cafes, and food parks featuring cuisines from all over the world. It‚Äôs a must-visit for foodies looking to explore local and international dishes.

Travel Tip: Go with an empty stomach and an adventurous palate‚Äîthere‚Äôs a lot to try, and the offerings can be quite unique!

5. La Mesa Eco Park

La Mesa Eco Park is a public park situated at the La Mesa Watershed, the primary source of drinking water for Metro Manila. The park is an oasis with its forest, picnic spots, bike trails, and a reservoir.

Travel Tip: Bring insect repellent and sun protection if you plan to hike or take a boat ride, as you‚Äôll be amidst nature.

6. EDSA Shrine

The EDSA Shrine is an important historical and religious site that commemorates the People Power Revolution of 1986. It‚Äôs a small church located at the crossroads of EDSA and Ortigas Avenue and is a symbol of peace and freedom.

Travel Tip: Visit on a weekday if you prefer a quieter time to reflect, as the area can be quite busy during weekends.

7. Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center

The Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center is a zoo and botanical garden that offers a pleasant escape from the city‚Äôs bustle. The park serves as a sanctuary for various Philippine flora and fauna, some of which are rescued and rehabilitated.

Travel Tip: Don‚Äôt miss the Wildlife Rescue Center within the park where you can learn about conservation efforts for Philippine wildlife.

8. Smart Araneta Coliseum

Also known as the Big Dome, the Smart Araneta Coliseum is an indoor multi-purpose sports arena that has hosted everything from basketball games to large religious gatherings and international concerts.

Travel Tip: Check the event schedule online; if something interests you, it‚Äôs advisable to purchase tickets in advance as they often sell out quickly.

9. Sining Kamalig

Sining Kamalig is a gallery that provides a platform for contemporary Filipino artists to showcase their work. The exhibits here are dynamic and reflect the vibrant art scene in Quezon City.

Travel Tip: The gallery is relatively small, so consider combining your visit with other activities in the Ali Mall area.

Quezon City, Philippines: Ratings

Kid-Friendly Activities in Quezon City: 8/10 ‚Äì Quezon City offers a variety of family-friendly attractions, including the Quezon Memorial Circle with its playgrounds and picnic areas, the Ninoy Aquino Parks and Wildlife Center, and interactive museums like the Mind Museum. The city‚Äôs numerous parks and malls with play zones also provide plenty of activities for children.

Nightlife in Quezon City: 8/10 ‚Äì Quezon City has a vibrant nightlife scene, particularly in areas like Tomas Morato, Eastwood City, and Timog Avenue. The city offers a wide range of bars, clubs, live music venues, and late-night restaurants, catering to different tastes and ensuring lively evening entertainment.

Sport in Quezon City: 7/10 ‚Äì Quezon City provides good opportunities for sports, including basketball, badminton, and tennis in various sports centers and clubs. The city also has numerous gyms and fitness centers, as well as public parks suitable for jogging and other outdoor activities.

Culture and Attractions in Quezon City: 7/10 ‚Äì Quezon City is rich in cultural and historical attractions, such as the Quezon Memorial Shrine, the University of the Philippines Diliman campus, and various art galleries and theaters. The city‚Äôs diverse cultural scene includes festivals, live performances, and historical landmarks.

Gastronomy in Quezon City: 8/10 ‚Äì The culinary scene in Quezon City is diverse, offering a mix of traditional Filipino cuisine and international dishes. The city‚Äôs numerous restaurants, food parks, and street food stalls provide a wide range of dining experiences, from casual eateries to fine dining.

Shopping in Quezon City: 8/10 ‚Äì Shopping in Quezon City includes modern malls like Trinoma, SM North EDSA, and Vertis North, which offer a variety of local and international brands. The city also has numerous markets and shopping districts where visitors can find unique items and bargains.

Prices in Quezon City: 8/10 ‚Äì Quezon City is relatively affordable, with reasonable prices for accommodation, dining, and entertainment. The city offers a good value for money, making it accessible for budget-conscious travelers.

Average price for a hotel night: $60

Cost of a lunch at a local restaurant: $8

Price of a beer: $2

Price of a coffee: $2.50

Beyond the City: Exploring Surroundings and Stays in Quezon City, Philippines

For those looking to explore beyond the urban sprawl, top day trips near Quezon City offer a chance to immerse in the natural beauty and cultural richness of the Philippines. From the refreshing waters of Daranak Falls to the historical charm of Intramuros, each destination provides a unique escape from the city life.

When it comes to finding the perfect place to stay, Quezon City accommodations range from cozy, boutique hotels nestled in vibrant neighborhoods to luxurious high-rises with panoramic city views, ensuring every traveler finds a comfortable base to experience this dynamic metropolis.
